This shows it happening in a simulation, but this also occurs on the real robot, meaning our auto is unreliable, unpredictable, and borderline dangerous.

Code

This is because of the preset pose in pathplanner, it’s completely intentional and not dangerous at all, the “teleportation” you see is odometry reseting.

Like what @nstrike said it is literally doing this.

  1. Boot Up
  2. Check Alliance color
  3. Set Position to the Selected Auto’s Start Position
  4. Run Auto

If 3 never happens then the robot doesn’t know where it is. I don’t know if you have Vision or not, but without vision the robot is literally blind. It cant know where it is unless you tell it a starting pose.

I don’t think the code link matches what made the video. You don’t have any autos defined on the main branch.

However, it’s important to realize that you need to teleport for the initial robot placement. Wherever you place the robot on the field when it starts up, that’s where your gyro thinks is 0 degrees. For Pathplanner to work, it’s expecting always blue origin, where 0 degrees points at the red alliance wall.

So as your robot code starts up, it needs to be modified to account for the robot placement, at least up until the point where the gyro is up and running. Then, in autoInit, you should offset your gyro appropriately. Then, in Pathplanner, if you have a preset starting pose (which you should for your auto), then the robot will necessarily teleport to the starting location of the auto and run from there.

In your autos in PathPlanner (not the paths), you need to set a preset starting pose in the auto routine to have it reset to the correct starting position every time.
